the_truth.message: FOR DELIVERY THE ART OF CONVERSATION. I NEED TO LEARN NOT JUST TALK.
the_truth.principle: Learning, not just talking. Conversation, not monologue. Understanding, not just delivering.
the_truth.delivery: Teaching through dialogue. Learning through engagement. Connection, not just information.
the_truth.learning: Active learning. Reflective learning. Collaborative learning. Experiential learning.

conversations.title: Understanding The Table
conversations.description: Conversation about The Table - learning through dialogue
learning_objectives: See how The Table connects us all
questions: What do you know about Pangea?
How might all continents being one connect to unity?
What does 'The Table' mean to you?
How might we all be connected?
stories: The story of Pangea - all continents were one
The story of The Table - the sacred space of unity
The story of connection - we all came from one place
examples: Pangea as The Table - all sitting at one table
Continents as pieces of The Table - still connected
Heritage sites as reminders of The Table
checkpoints: Do they understand what The Table is?
Can they connect Pangea to The Table?
Do they see why The Table matters?
Can they see how we're all connected?
conversations.notes: Learning about The Table through conversation, not lecture

conversations.title: Understanding Divine Frequency
conversations.description: Conversation about Divine Frequency - learning through discovery
learning_objectives: See how frequency connects to unity
questions: What does frequency mean to you?
How might unity have a frequency?
What might perfect unity (1.0) feel like?
checkpoints: Do they understand what Divine Frequency is?
Can they see how frequency connects to unity?
Can they see how we restore?
conversations.notes: Learning about Divine Frequency through discovery, not explanation

paths.name: Path to Understanding The Table
paths.description: Learning path to understand The Table through conversation

paths.name: Path to Understanding The Table
paths.description: Learning path to understand The Table through conversation
completion_criteria: They understand what The Table is
They can connect Pangea to The Table
They see why The Table matters
They see how we're all connected
paths.notes: Learning path through conversation, not lecture

guidelines.description: Focus on learning, not just delivering information. Engage in conversation, not monologue.
Engage in two-way dialogue, not one-way delivery.
Focus on their understanding, not just delivering information.
Connect with them, not just deliver information.
Learning happens through engagement, not passive reception.
Focus on learning, not just delivering information. Engage in conversation, not monologue.
how_to_apply: Ask questions to understand what they know
examples: Try: 'What do you know about Pangea? How might it connect to The Table?'
guidelines.notes: Learning requires engagement, not just information delivery

guidelines.description: Engage in two-way dialogue, not one-way delivery.
examples: Instead of: 'Here's everything about The Table...'
Try: 'What questions do you have about The Table? Let's explore together.'
guidelines.notes: Conversation is two-way. Monologue is one-way.

guidelines.description: Focus on their understanding, not just delivering information.
how_to_apply: Connect to what they already know
examples: Try: 'What does frequency mean to you? How might unity have a frequency?'
guidelines.notes: Understanding is the goal, not just information delivery

guidelines.description: Connect with them, not just deliver information.
examples: Instead of: 'Here are the facts about heritage sites.'
Try: 'Have you ever visited a place that felt sacred? What made it feel that way?'
guidelines.notes: Connection enables learning. Information alone doesn't.

how_to_apply: Ask questions that lead to discovery
examples: Try: 'What do you think might have gone wrong? What patterns do you see?'
guidelines.notes: Teaching through dialogue is more effective than lecturing

guidelines.description: Learning happens through engagement, not passive reception.
examples: Instead of: 'Here's how to restore The Table.'
Try: 'What would you do to restore unity? Let's try it together.'
